Leah Camille Aden, NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund, Inc. ... Adriel I. Cepeda Derieux, American Civil Liberties Union Foundation

extracted.value: Plaintiffs: public interest organization such as the ACLU

evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief, Three Judge Panel Requested
evidence.text: 19. Plaintiff THE SOUTH CAROLINA STATE CONFERENCE OF THE NAACP (“South Carolina NAACP”) is a nonprofit, nonpartisan membership organization in South Carolina. The South Carolina NAACP is a state conference of branches of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (“NAACP”), a national civil rights organization. The South Carolina NAACP was chartered in 1939 and is the oldest civil rights group in South Carolina.

extracted.value: Plaintiff: THE SOUTH CAROLINA STATE CONFERENCE OF THE NAACP, a nonprofit, nonpartisan membership organization chartered in 1939 and the oldest civil rights group in South Carolina

evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief, Three Judge Panel Requested
evidence.text: 28. Plaintiff TAIWAN SCOTT is a U.S. citizen and Black, registered voter, and resident of Hilton Head in Beaufort County, South Carolina. Specifically, Mr. Scott resides in CD1, which is overpopulated based on 2020 Census data. Mr. Scott and members of his family, who have lived in Hilton Head for seven generations, are Gullah people, descendants of West African people who were enslaved and forcibly brought to America’s southeastern coast, including South Carolina’s coastal plain and Beaufort Sea Islands.

extracted.value: Plaintiff: TAIWAN SCOTT, a U.S. citizen and Black, registered voter, resident of Hilton Head in Beaufort County, South Carolina, a Gullah person with seven generations of family in Hilton Head

evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief, Three Judge Panel Requested
evidence.text: 29. Defendant HENRY D. MCMASTER, in his official capacity as Governor of South Carolina, is a proper defendant because, under Article IV, Section 21 of the South Carolina Constitution, he possesses the authority to sign or veto any redistricting plan passed by the Legislature. Defendant McMaster also has the authority under Article IV, Section 19 of the South Carolina Constitution to convene the General Assembly for extra sessions, including to address redistricting.

extracted.value: Defendant: HENRY D. MCMASTER, in his official capacity as Governor of South Carolina

evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief, Three Judge Panel Requested
evidence.text: 30. Defendant HARVEY PEELER, in his official capacity as President of the South Carolina Senate, is a proper defendant as leader of the Senate, which drafts and passes reapportionment legislation for consideration by the General Assembly.

extracted.value: Defendant: HARVEY PEELER, in his official capacity as President of the South Carolina Senate

evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief, Three Judge Panel Requested
evidence.text: 31. Defendant LUKE A. RANKIN, in his official capacity as Chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, is a proper defendant as leader of the committee responsible for drafting and passing reapportionment legislation for consideration by the full Senate.

extracted.value: Defendant: LUKE A. RANKIN, in his official capacity as Chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee

evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief, Three Judge Panel Requested
evidence.text: 32. Defendant JAMES H. LUCAS, in his official capacity as Speaker of the South Carolina House of Representatives, is a proper defendant as leader of the House charged with presiding over the House and ratifying bills upon passage by both houses of the Legislature pursuant to Article III, Section 18 of the South Carolina Constitution.

extracted.value: Defendant: JAMES H. LUCAS, in his official capacity as Speaker of the South Carolina House of Representatives

evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief, Three Judge Panel Requested
evidence.text: 33. Defendant CHRIS MURPHY, in his official capacity as Chairman of the Judiciary Committee of the House of Representatives, is a proper defendant as leader of the committee responsible for drafting and passing reapportionment legislation for consideration by the full House.

extracted.value: Defendant: CHRIS MURPHY, in his official capacity as Chairman of the Judiciary Committee of the House of Representatives

evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief, Three Judge Panel Requested
evidence.text: 34. Defendant WALLACE H. JORDAN, in his official capacity as Chairman of the Election Laws Subcommittee of the House of Representatives, is a proper defendant as leader of the subcommittee responsible for drafting and passing reapportionment legislation for consideration by the Judiciary Committee of the House of Representatives and the full House.

extracted.value: Defendant: WALLACE H. JORDAN, in his official capacity as Chairman of the Election Laws Subcommittee of the House of Representatives

evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief, Three Judge Panel Requested
evidence.text: 35. Defendant HOWARD KNABB, in his official capacity as the interim Executive Director of the South Carolina State Election Commission, is a proper defendant as the head of the South Carolina agency responsible for implementing and conducting elections pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. §§ 7-3-10, et seq. and 7-13-10, et seq., as amended.

extracted.value: Defendant: HOWARD KNABB, in his official capacity as interim Executive Director of the South Carolina State Election Commission

evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief, Three Judge Panel Requested
evidence.text: 36. Defendants JOHN WELLS, JOANNE DAY, CLIFFORD J. ELDER, LINDA MCCALL, and SCOTT MOSELEY, in their official capacities as members of the South Carolina State Election Commission, are proper defendants as persons charged with the powers and duties of the South Carolina State Election Commission pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. §§ 7-3-10, et seq. and 7-13-10, et seq., as amended.

extracted.value: Defendant: JOHN WELLS, JOANNE DAY, CLIFFORD J. ELDER, LINDA MCCALL, and SCOTT MOSELEY, in their official capacities as members of the South Carolina State Election Commission
